properties.media:imagetext:
TO SIT IN AN EXIT ROW
In order to ensure the fastest possible emergency
evacuation, the Federal Aviation Administration has set
standards for people who sit in rows next to exits. Passen-
gers sitting in exit rows must :
1) Read English well enough to understand the
instructions for opening exits and for other emergency
procedures;
2) See well enough to read these instructions, to see
signals given by crewmembers and to look outside for
dangers such as smoke, fire or water which would make
the exit unusable. You can wear glasses or contact lenses;
3) Hear well enough to understand English com-
mands. You can use a hearing aid;
4) Speak well enough to give information in English
to crewmembers or other passengers during an emergency;
5) Be able to use both hands, both arms and both
legs, as well as be strong and flexible enough to quickly
open the exit and go out through it. Be able to clear the
exit row of obstructions. Some window hatches that must
be lifted can weigh as much as 65 pounds (30 kgs), the
average weight of a 7 year old child;
6) Be willing to help other passengers away from the
plane;
7) Be at least 15 years of age;
8) Be with no one that requires your care, such as a
small child, or someone physically or mentally unable to
care for themselves.
You must be willing and able to do all of these things by
yourself and without harming yourself.
If you cannot do all these things, you cannot sit in an
exit row. If you are already seated there ask the flight
attendant to move you to another seat. You do not have
to explain why. You need to say only, "I do not want to sit
in an exit row."
ML-0476
millsfield:images_texts:
GATE 47
OBEY
1.
FASTEN SEATBELTS
2.
3.
NO SMOKING 1*
BE PREPARED... To assist crewmembers in an emer-
gency, follow the guidelines below. Passengers should
open exits only if a flight attendant cannot reach the exit.
1) Know where all the exits are on this aircraft.
Study the briefing card and know how to open the exit
closest to you.
2) If an emergency evacuation is necessary, and if a
flight attendant cannot get to the exit in your row, you may
have to open it. First, look outside. If fire, smoke, or
water could come into the cabin through the exit, don't
open it.
3) If it is safe to open the exit, do so as quickly as
possible. Keep the pathway to the exit clear. If the exit
cannot be opened, go to another exit.
4) If the exit has an inflatable emergency slide, you
may have to inflate it. Check the briefing card to see how.
When it is inflated, shout "Release seatbelts! Come this
way!" Then go out the exit as quickly as possible.
5) If there is a slide, and there's no immediate dan-
ger, wait at the bottom to help people off the slide. Hold
onto the slide to stabilize it.
6) Move away from the aircraft as soon and as
quickly as you can.
Thank you for your assistance
in helping us meet these FAA requirements.
Midway Airlines®
WHAT FLYING SHOULD BE™

Tumwater, WA, USA. All rights reserved. 905
